chapter.title: FAQ
chapter.subtitle: Frequently Asked Questions
chapter.para: This chapter answers the questions most frequently asked on &C2; mailing lists. As it extensively links to further sections of the manual, it can also be treated as some sort question-based index for this manual.

question.para: Can I use &C2; in a commercial project?

answer.para: Yes. The only requirement is that you properly acknowledge the use of &C2; (on your project's website and documentation) and let us know about your project. Please also remember to read the license.

question.para: How can I acknowledge the use of &C2; on my site?

answer.para: Please put a statement equivalent to This product includes software developed by the &C2; Project on your site and link it to &C2;'s website (). Additionally, you can use some of our powered-by logos if you like.

question.para: Can I use &C2; to cluster something else than search results?

answer.para: Absolutely. &C2; came about as a framework for building search results clustering engines but its algorithms should successfully cluster up to about a thousand text documents, a few paragraphs each.

question.para: How does &C2; clustering scale with respect to the number and length of documents?

answer.para: The most important characteristic of &PROD; algorithms to keep in mind is that they perform in-memory clustering. For this reason, as a rule of thumb, &PROD; should successfully deal with up to a thousand of documents, a few paragraphs each. For algorithms designed to process millions of documents, you may want to check out the Mahout project.

question.para: Can I force &C2; to cluster my documents to some predefined clusters / labels?

answer.para: No. Assigning documents to a set of predefined categories is a problem called text classification / categorization and &C2; was not designed to solve it. For text classification components you may want to see the LingPipe project.

question.para: Can &C2; cluster content in other languages than English?

answer.para:
Yes. Currently, Carrot2 can cluster content in 17 languages:
Chinese Simplified (experimental) Danish Dutch English Finnish French German Hungarian Italian Norwegian Polish Portuguese Romanian Russian Spanish Swedish Turkish
Please note, however, that for some of the languages you may need to tune the stop words to achieve best results.

question.para: What is the query syntax in &C2;?

answer.para: As &C2; is not a search engine on its own, there is no common query syntax in &C2;. The syntax depends on the underlying search engine you set &C2; to use, e.g. Yahoo!, Solr, Lucene or any other. &C2; passes your query without any modifications to the search engine and clusters the results it returns. For this reason, any syntax supported by the search engine is automatically supported in &C2;.
If the underlying search engine support boolean queries, so will &C2;. Please see this question for more details.
